[[Rollo Davidson Prize]] (2006) |signature = |footnotes = }} '''Scott Sheffield''' (born October 20, 1973) is a professor of [[mathematics]] at the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]].http://math.mit.edu/people/profile.php?pid=243, MIT, retrieved 2013-23-08. His primary research field is theoretical probability. ==Research== Much of Sheffield's work examines conformal invariant objects which arise in the study of two-dimensional statistical physics models. He studies the [[Schramm-Loewner evolution]] SLE(κ) and its relations to a variety of other random objects. For example, he proved that SLE describes the interface between two Liouville quantum gravity surfaces that have been [[conformal welding|conformally welded]] together.Conformal weldings of random surfaces: SLE and the quantum gravity zipper, Scott Sheffield, 2010, http://arxiv.org/abs/1012.4797 In joint work with Oded Schramm, he showed that contour lines of the [[Gaussian free field]] are related to SLE(4).Contour lines of the two-dimensional discrete Gaussian free field, Oded Schramm and Scott Sheffield, 2006, http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0605337A contour line of the continuum Gaussian free field, Oded Schramm and Scott Sheffield, 2010, http://arxiv.org/abs/1008.2447 With Jason Miller, he developed the theory of Gaussian free field flow lines, which include SLE(κ) for all values of κ, as well as many variants of SLE.Imaginary Geometry I: Interacting SLEs, Jason Miller and Scott Sheffield, 2012, http://arxiv.org/abs/1201.1496 Sheffield and Bertrand Duplantier proved the Knizhnik-Polyakov-Zamolodchikov (KPZ) relation for fractal scaling dimensions in Liouville quantum gravity.Liouville Quantum Gravity and KPZ, Bertrand Duplantier and Scott Sheffield, 2008, http://arxiv.org/abs/0808.1560 Sheffield also defined the [[conformal loop ensemble]]s, which serve as scaling limits of the collection of all interfaces in various statistical physics models.Exploration trees and conformal loop ensembles, Scott Sheffield, 2006, http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0609167 In joint work with [[Wendelin Werner]], he described the conformal loop ensembles as the outer boundaries of clusters of Brownian loops.Conformal loop ensembles: the Markovian characterization and loop soup construction, Scott Sheffield and Wendelin Werner, 2010, http://arxiv.org/abs/1006.2374 In addition to these contributions, Sheffield has also proved results regarding internal [[diffusion limited aggregation]], [[domino tiling|dimers]], [[game theory]], [[partial differential equations]], and Lipschitz extension theory.2011 Loève Prize announcement, http://www.stat.berkeley.edu/users/aldous/Research/sheffield.pdf ==Education and Career== Sheffield graduated from [[Harvard University]] in 1998 with an A.B. and A.M. in mathematics. In 2003, he received his Ph.D. in mathematics from [[Stanford University]]. Before becoming a professor at MIT, Sheffield held postdoctoral positions at [[Microsoft Research]], the [[University of California at Berkeley]], and the [[Institute for Advanced Study]]. He was also an associate professor at [[New York University]].http://math.mit.edu/~sheffield/cv.html, MIT, retrieved 2013-23-08 ==Awards== Scott Sheffield received the [[Loève Prize]], the [[Presidential Early Career Award for Scientists and Engineers]], the [[Sloan Research Fellowship]], and the [[Rollo Davidson Prize]].
